## Data visualization

Why graphs?

- *"... to help us perceive broad features of the data"*
- *"... to let us ... see what else is there."*

[@anscombe_1973]

## Four data sets - Anscombe's quartet

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em; text-align: center"}

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| warning: false

library(datasets); library(tidyverse); library(knitr); library(broom)

data("anscombe")

 anscombe %>%
      mutate(obs = seq(1:11)) %>%
        pivot_longer(names_to = "var", values_to = "values", 
                     cols = x1:y4) %>%
        separate(var, 
           into = c("var", "pair"), 
           sep = "(?<=[A-Za-z])(?=[0-9])"
           ) %>%
        group_by(pair, var) %>%
         summarise(mean = mean(values), 
                   sd = sd(values), 
                   min = min(values), 
                   max = max(values)) %>%
         arrange(var) %>%
         dplyr::select(Dataset = pair, Variable = var, Mean = mean, SD = sd, Min = min, Max = max) %>%
         kable(caption = "Summary statistics for Anscombe's data", digits = 1)
```

:::

[@anscombe_1973]

## Anscombe's quartet (2)

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em; text-align: center"}

```{r}
anscombe %>%
      mutate(obs = seq(1:11)) %>%
        pivot_longer(names_to = "var", values_to = "values", 
                     cols = x1:y4) %>%
        separate(var, 
           into = c("var", "pair"), 
           sep = "(?<=[A-Za-z])(?=[0-9])"
           ) %>%
            pivot_wider(names_from = var, values_from = values) %>%
         group_by(pair) %>%
         do(intercept = coef(lm(y ~ x, data = .))[1], 
            slope = coef(lm(y ~ x, data = .))[2], 
            cor = round(cor(.$x, .$y), 2)) %>%
         unnest(cols = c(intercept, slope)) %>%
         dplyr::select(Dataset = pair, Intercept = intercept, Slope = slope, Correlation = cor) %>%
         kable(caption = "Regression coeficients for for Anscombe's data", digits = 2)

```

:::
[@anscombe_1973]



## A best guess of the data pattern

```{r}
#| echo: false


data.frame(x = c(0, 20), 
           y = c(0, 13)) %>%
        ggplot(aes(x,y)) +
        
        geom_blank() +
        
        geom_abline(intercept = 3, slope = 0.5, color = "steelblue", 
                    size = 2) +

        geom_point(data = data.frame(x = 9, y = 7.5), 
                   aes(), size = 3) + 
        geom_errorbar(aes(y = 7.5,x = 9, ymin = 7.5 - 2, ymax = 7.5 + 2)) +
        geom_errorbarh(aes(y = 7.5,x = 9, xmin = 9 - 3.3, xmax = 9 + 3.3))





```



## Plotting the actual data

```{r}
#| echo: false

library(datasets); library(tidyverse)

data("anscombe")

anscombe %>%
      mutate(obs = seq(1:11)) %>%
        pivot_longer(names_to = "var", values_to = "values", 
                     cols = x1:y4) %>%
        separate(var, 
           into = c("var", "pair"), 
           sep = "(?<=[A-Za-z])(?=[0-9])"
           ) %>%
        pivot_wider(names_from = var, values_from = values) %>%
        
        group_by(pair) %>%
        mutate(pair = paste0("Data set ", pair)) %>%
        
        
        
        ggplot(aes(x, y)) + geom_point(shape = 21, size = 3, fill = "steelblue") + 
        
        scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 13)) + 
        scale_x_continuous(limits = c(0, 20)) +
        
        
        facet_wrap(~ pair)





```

## Another example - The `Datasaurus`


::: {style="font-size: 0.5em; text-align: center"}

```{r}
#| echo: false

library(datasauRus)

datasaurus_dozen %>% 
    group_by(dataset) %>% 
    summarize(
      mean_x    = mean(x),
      mean_y    = mean(y),
      std_dev_x = sd(x),
      std_dev_y = sd(y),
      corr_x_y  = cor(x, y)
    ) %>%
        kable(col.names = c("Dataset", "Mean x", "Mean y", 
                            "SD x", "SD y", "Correlation"), 
              caption = "The Datasaurus datasets", digits = 2)





```

:::

## A system for creating graphs in R

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| fig-width: 9
#| fig-height: 3
#| fig-cap: "Three layers of a graph, geometric objects, scales and coordinates and annotations of the plot"

dat <- data.frame(x = c(2, 1, 4, 9), 
                  y = c(4, 1, 15, 80), 
                  shape = c("a", "a", "b", "b"))


points <- dat %>%
        ggplot(aes(x, y, shape = shape)) + 
        geom_point(size = 4) + 
        theme_void() + 
        theme(legend.position = "none")

scales <- dat %>%
        ggplot(aes(x, y, shape = shape)) + 
        geom_blank() + 
        theme_bw() + 
        theme(legend.position = "none")

annot <- dat %>%
        ggplot(aes(x, y, shape = shape)) + 
        geom_blank() + 
        theme_void() + 
        theme(legend.position = "none") + 
        labs(title = "Graph title", 
             caption = "Graph caption")

full <- dat %>%
        ggplot(aes(x, y, shape = shape)) + 
        geom_point(size = 4) + 
        theme_bw() + 
        theme(legend.position = "none")+ 
        labs(title = "Graph title", 
             caption = "Graph caption")


library(cowplot)

plot_grid(points, scales, annot, nrow = 1)


```

## `ggplot2` - Grammar of graphics

- `data` &rarr; The dataset containing variables to plot
- `aes`thetics &rarr; Scales where the data are mapped
- `geom`etries &rarr; Geometric representations of the data
- `facet` &rarr; A part of the dataset
- `stat`istical transformations &rarr; Summaries of data
- `coord`inates &rarr; The coordinate space
- `theme`s &rarr; Plot components not linked to data

## Common types of plots - Frequencies and densities 



```{r}
#| echo: false
#| warning: false
#| message: false
#| fig-cap: "A continuous variable displayed in a Histogram and Density plot"

set.seed(1)
library(patchwork)

dat <- data.frame(category = c(rep("A", 5), rep("B", 25), rep("C", 125)),
           value = c(rnorm(5, 25, 10), 
                     rnorm(25, 25, 10), 
                     rnorm(125, 25, 10)))


a <- dat %>%
        ggplot(aes(value)) + geom_histogram()

b <-  dat %>% 
        ggplot(aes(value)) + geom_density()


a | b



```


## Common types of plots - Comparing categories

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| warning: false
#| message: false
#| fig-cap: "Comparison of a continous variable between categories using summary graphics"


a <- dat %>%
        ggplot(aes(category, value)) + geom_boxplot() + 
        scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 50), expand = c(0, 0))

b <- dat %>%
        group_by(category) %>%
        summarise(s = sd(value), 
                  value = mean(value)) %>%
        ggplot(aes(category, value)) + 
        geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = value, ymax = value + s), width = 0.4) +
        geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "steelblue", color = "black") +

        scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 50), expand = c(0, 0))



a | b

```



## Common types of plots - Comparing categories without hiding data


```{r}
#| echo: false
#| warning: false
#| message: false
#| fig-cap: "Comparison of a continous variable between categories using summary graphics"


a <- dat %>%
        group_by(category) %>%
        summarise(s = sd(value), 
                  value = mean(value)) %>%
        ggplot(aes(category, value)) + 
        geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = value, ymax = value + s), width = 0.4) +
        geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "steelblue", color = "black") +

        scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 50), expand = c(0, 0))



b <- dat %>%
        ggplot(aes(category, value)) + geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2)) + 
        scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 50), expand = c(0, 0))



a | b

```



## Common types of plots - Comparing categories highlighting differences


```{r}
#| echo: false
#| warning: false
#| message: false
#| fig-cap: "Comparison of a continous variable between categories using raw data and summaries"


b <- dat %>%
        ggplot(aes(category, value, fill = category)) + geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2), 
                                                  alpha = 0.4, shape = 21) + 
        scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 50), expand = c(0, 0)) +
        stat_summary(fun=mean, geom="point", shape = 21, aes(fill = category), size = 3)



b

```

## Common types of plots - Relationships between continuous variables

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| warning: false
#| message: false
#| fig-cap: "Highlighting relationships, raw data and summaries"

set.seed(1)

dat <- data.frame(x = rnorm(100, 50, 25)) %>%
        mutate(y = 10 + 0.5 * x + rnorm(100, 0, 5), 
               y2 = 10 + 0.5 * x + x^2 * 0.01 + rnorm(100, 0, 25))
        

a <- dat %>% 
        ggplot(aes(x = x, y = y)) + geom_point() +
        
        scale_y_continuous(limits = c(-10, 90))


b <- dat %>% 
        ggplot(aes(x = x, y = y)) + geom_point() +
        geom_smooth(method = "lm") +
        
        scale_y_continuous(limits = c(-10, 90))


c <- dat %>% 
        ggplot(aes(x = x, y = y2)) + geom_point() +
        geom_smooth() 




a | b | c



```
